skill.name: nuxt
skill.description: Nuxt full-stack Vue framework with SSR, auto-imports, and file-based routing. Use when working with Nuxt apps, server routes, useFetch, middleware, or hybrid rendering.
skill.summary: Full-stack Vue framework documentation covering SSR, file-based routing, auto-imports, and the Nitro server engine for universal deployment.
skill.author: antfu

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing markdown reference files about the Nuxt framework. Static analysis detected patterns in documentation text (code examples, URLs, environment variable references) that were flagged as security issues. These are false positives since this skill contains no executable code - it only provides framework documentation to help AI agents understand Nuxt concepts. The skill is safe for publication.

content.value_statement: Developing full-stack Vue applications requires understanding server-side rendering, file-based routing, and the Nuxt module ecosystem. This skill provides comprehensive documentation for building production-ready Nuxt applications with the Nitro server engine.
actual_capabilities: Explain Nuxt project structure and directory conventions for pages, components, and composables
Guide on configuring nuxt.config.ts with runtime config, app.config, and environment variables
Describe data fetching patterns using useFetch, useAsyncData, and $fetch with caching
Document server routes and API creation using the Nitro engine with file-based API handlers
Explain rendering modes including SSR, SPA, and hybrid rendering with route rules
Provide guidance on state management with useState, Pinia integration, and SSR-safe patterns
limitations: This skill provides documentation only and does not execute code or modify user projects
Skill does not install dependencies, run build commands, or interact with package managers
Does not provide debugging capabilities or runtime error analysis for existing applications

use_cases.title: Set up a new Nuxt project
use_cases.description: Use this skill when initializing a new Nuxt application, configuring the project structure, and understanding the default directory conventions for pages, layouts, and components.
use_cases.target_user: Developers new to Nuxt who need guidance on project setup and structure

use_cases.title: Build server API routes
use_cases.description: Learn how to create API endpoints using Nuxt server routes, handle request/response, and organize server utilities with the Nitro engine.
use_cases.target_user: Backend developers building APIs within Nuxt applications

use_cases.title: Optimize data fetching
use_cases.description: Understand best practices for fetching data in Nuxt including parallel requests, caching strategies, and avoiding hydration mismatches in SSR contexts.

prompt_templates.title: Getting started with Nuxt
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to build a Nuxt 3 application. Explain the project structure, including the pages directory, components folder, and composables. What are the key directories and their purposes?
prompt_templates.scenario: When starting a new Nuxt project and needing an overview of the directory structure

prompt_templates.title: Configuring Nuxt
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I configure my Nuxt application? I need to understand nuxt.config.ts, the difference between runtime config and app config, and how to use environment variables.
prompt_templates.scenario: When configuring a Nuxt application with different environments

prompt_templates.title: Data fetching patterns
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain the different ways to fetch data in Nuxt 3. When should I use useFetch versus useAsyncData? How do I handle caching and parallel requests?
prompt_templates.scenario: When implementing data fetching in a Nuxt page or component

prompt_templates.title: Server routes and API
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create API routes in Nuxt using the Nitro server? Show me how to create a file-based API endpoint, handle different HTTP methods, and access request body and query parameters.
prompt_templates.scenario: When building backend API endpoints within a Nuxt application

output_examples.input: What is the Nuxt directory structure?
output_examples.output:
Nuxt uses a file-based directory structure. The key directories are:

- `pages/` - Auto-generated routes based on Vue files in this directory
- `components/` - Components are auto-imported and available without explicit imports
- `composables/` - Vue composables auto-imported for logic reuse
- `layouts/` - Page layouts wrapper for consistent page structure
- `middleware/` - Route middleware for navigation guards
- `plugins/` - Vue plugins to extend the application
- `server/` - Server routes and API endpoints using Nitro
- `utils/` - Utility functions auto-imported across the app
- `app.vue` - Main application component entry point
- `nuxt.config.ts` - Nuxt configuration file

output_examples.input: How do I use environment variables in Nuxt?

best_practices: Use useFetch for data fetching in pages and components as it handles loading states, errors, and caching automatically
Configure route rules to enable swr or ISR caching for pages that do not need real-time data
Keep sensitive configuration in runtime config and expose only what is needed through public runtime config
anti_patterns: Do not manually import components from the components directory - Nuxt auto-imports them
Avoid using process.env directly in components - use runtime config instead for proper hydration
Do not make API calls in the setup function without proper error handling - use useFetch with error handling

faq.question: What is the difference between useFetch and useAsyncData?
faq.answer: useFetch is the recommended wrapper around useAsyncData that provides a simpler API. useAsyncData gives you more control over the data fetching lifecycle while useFetch handles common patterns automatically including type inference and error handling.

faq.question: How does file-based routing work in Nuxt?
faq.answer: Nuxt automatically generates routes from the pages/ directory. Each Vue file becomes a route based on its file path. Dynamic routes use square bracket notation like [id].vue for parameters.

faq.question: What rendering modes does Nuxt support?
faq.answer: Nuxt supports universal rendering (SSR), client-side rendering (SPA), and hybrid rendering. You can configure per-page rendering using route rules in nuxt.config.ts.

faq.question: How do I create a server API route in Nuxt?
faq.answer: Create .ts files in the server/api/ directory. The file path determines the route URL. Use defineEventHandler to handle requests and readBody or getQuery to access request data.

faq.question: What is the Nitro server engine?
faq.answer: Nitro is Nuxt's server engine that powers server routes, API endpoints, and SSR. It provides a unified API for building serverless-friendly applications that deploy to any platform.

faq.question: How do I manage state in Nuxt?
faq.answer: Use useState for simple shared state that is SSR-safe. For complex state management, integrate Pinia which has official Nuxt support. Both work seamlessly with server-side rendering.
